title: Limited Edition Shop
statementHtml:
There is a shop with nn objects numbered from 11 to nn, and only one copy of each object. According to you, the objects have values v1,v2,…,vnv1,v2,…,vn (which can be negative).

Alice and Bob have their own order of preference of objects (a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an and b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn respectively). In particular, Alice's favourite object is a1a1, followed by a2a2, etc.; Bob's favourite object is b1b1, followed by b2b2, etc.

For nn times, one of them goes to the shop and buys her or his most favourite object still in the shop. At the end, Alice and Bob have their own sets of objects.

Now the shop is empty, and you wonder whether Alice's preferences are similar to yours. Over all sets of objects that Alice could have bought, what's the maximum sum of values according to you?
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of objects.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers v1,v2,…,vnv1,v2,…,vn (−109≤vi≤109−109≤vi≤109) — the values of the objects, according to you.

The third line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — Alice's order of preference. The aiai are distinct.

The fourth line of each test case contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤n1≤bi≤n) — Bob's order of preference. The bibi are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer: the maximum sum of values over all sets of objects that Alice could have bought.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, Alice can buy the sets of objects [][] (empty), [1][1], [3][3], [3,1][3,1], [3,1,2][3,1,2] (the objects are ordered by purchase time). For example, for Alice to buy [1][1], the two can enter the store in the following order:

  • Bob enters and buys object 22;
  • Bob enters and buys object 33 (object 22 is sold out);
  • Alice enters and buys object 11 (object 33 is sold out).

The set of objects with maximum total value according to you is [3,1][3,1], which has value v3+v1=2v3+v1=2.

In the second test case, Alice's and Bob's preferences are the same as in the first test case, but now the set of objects with maximum total value is [3,1,2][3,1,2], with value 55.
